awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating Physics and Generative Machine Learning Models for Inverse Materials Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is aimed to address a grand challenge in data-intensive materials science and engineering to find better materials with desired properties, often with the goal to enhance performance in specific applications. This project addresses this grand challenge with a specific focus on finding metal organic framework (MOF) materials that are used to separate gas mixtures and finding better battery materials for energy storage. The PIs will combine theoretical methods from statistical mechanics and condensed-matter physics, and physics-based models, to generate information-rich materials data which is integrated with generative machine learning (ML) algorithms to search a complex chemical design space efficiently and to train deep learning models for fast screening of materials properties. This project will be carried out by a multidisciplinary collaboration involving researchers from physics, materials science and engineering, computer science, and mathematics. The resulting multidisciplinary environment fosters training the next generation data savvy scientists who will engage in collaborative multidisciplinary research.  

Existing approaches for computational design of metal organic frameworks (MOF) and solid-state electrolyte materials are largely based on screening of known materials or enumerative search of hypothetical materials. This project develops a new approach that integrates first principles calculations, experimental data and abundant data generated by physics-based models to train generalized antagonistic network (GAN) models for efficient search of the materials design space, and to train deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) models for fast and accurate screening of properties of the GAN-generated candidate materials. Additionally, graph-based GAN models will be used for MOF topology exploration and can be applied to other nanomaterials designs. More specifically, the investigators will: 1) develop and exploit physics-based models for fast calculation of properties such as diffusivity, ion conductivity, and mechanical stability; 2) develop generative adversarial network (GAN) models with built-in physics rules for efficient exploration of the chemical design space for both MOF materials and solid electrolytes; 3) use persistence homology and Bravais lattice sequence representations of MOF materials and solid electrolytes, respectively, to build Deep Convolutional Neural Network (DCNN) models for fast and accurate prediction of the physical properties of generated materials; 4)  apply high-level quantum-mechanical calculations for verification of discovered materials. Accomplishments from this project will lead to accelerated discovery of novel nanostructured materials for gas separation and energy storage, materials for lithium-ion batteries, novel data-driven scheme for materials design, and theoretical methods enabling implementation of advanced data science techniques. The highly interdisciplinary collaboration will offer students unique opportunities to interact with a variety of disciplines, and training the next-generation scientists with the mindset for multidiscipline collaborations. Educational and outreach activities will be developed and undertaken in conjunction with the proposed research activities.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity, and is jointly supported by HDR and the Division of Materials Research within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project set out on a two-year ideas lab project to combine machine learning with physics models to enable the inverse design of materials, i.e., the goal of finding materials with pre-specified properties. We focused on two classes of materials: metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for hydrogen storage and Li-on Solid State materials for batteries. We launched this study motivated by two tipping points:

Tipping Point A: Physics-based models enable efficient computation of material properties with sufficient accuracy to guide design.

Tipping Point B: Data-driving approaches are capable of fast and accurate generation and prediction, provided abundant training data are available.

To test tipping point A, we generated two physics-based models. We modeled the structural properties of MOFs with a high throughput algorithm that generates balls and springs networks from atom positions, including both linear springs between atoms and angular springs between two bonds. We find they are typically close to the isostatic point where the total number of springs K is equal to the number of degrees of freedom D = 3N, a basic observation that explains why MOFs are fragile but also suggests their structure should be studied using the recently established field of topological mechanics. We therefore propose that Maxwell counting, the difference K – D, is an important design property for MOFs, that, structural stability is efficiently captured by K-D.

We also constructed a lattice Coulomb gas model of Li-ion solid-state battery materials to capture the frustration of Li ions as they hop around their host crystal. Frustration here is captured by the number of options (states) the Li-ions can occupy at room temperature. We hypothesize that a high degree of frustration translates to high Li-ion superionic conductivity. We used tools from frustrated magnetism, specifically efficient Monte-Carlo algorithms, to compute entropy, the log of the number of states, to quickly assess frustration. We find this entropy directly tracks known expensive calculations of ion conductivity and so propose it as a property that can replace ion conductivity in the design of solid-state Li-ion batteries.

To test Tipping Point B, we directly addressed the MOF design problem. We developed components of a design pipeline, including

1. A spatial 3D grid blueprint of the MOF crystal’s unit cell, with channels capturing metal atom mass density, organic atom mass density, charge density, and the potential energy density of a Hydrogen atom test particle useful for designing hydrogen storage in fuel cells;

2. A generative adversarial neural network (GAN) trained on 60,000 MOF materials to generate new materials with similar blueprints to the training set;

3. High throughput screening of 3D grid blueprints using supervised machine learning.

In addition to these primary projects, we also carried out several tangential projects during early stages of the study that gave us experience in this field. This includes an early paper published in Machine Learning for Molecules Workshop at NeurIPS 2020 workshop identifying a machine learning algorithm for capturing inter-atomic potentials (see https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.15908), four contributed talks at the 2021 APS March meeting, and a poster presentation at the 2021 Knowledge Guided Machine Learning Workshop (https://par.nsf.gov/servlets/purl/10358018).

In total, three undergraduates, one masters, and three Ph.D. students have participated in this project. Two of these students have already entered the US workforce.
